Anne Hathaway plays a role reminiscent of the movie "The Devil Wears Prada" with her being a young employee with a much older boss.
This movie is the reversal; her a young boss with a much older employee, The Intern.
The movie overall has a good tone to it and makes you laugh every so often.
*SPOILER* On the contrast, much of the movie lacked any real plot that meets the casting.
Some of the story lines that are introduced are never revisited and don't leave you feeling satisfied with them.
For example one of the younger male employees is in love with Anne Hathways characters receptionist, they visit this story a couple times, but never put it to rest.
Another example would be her relationship with her mom.
Definitely a "date" movie, or a movie to watch with your mom... Anne and DeNiro are solid as always job and have a nice charm, but overall movie lacks substance.

Humorous look at the changing generational nuances of life.
Hathaway & De Niro shine throughout.
The Intern was a refreshing piece of cinema that dealt with the realities of ageism (specifically in the workplace) in a humorous and charming way.
The plot was well thought out, well acted, and entertaining.

Nancy Meyers has made a couple of films I have enjoyed, the now fairly forgotten What Women Want, where she got a good performance from Mel Gibson and paired him with an inform Helen Hunt, and then her following film, Something's Gotta Give, where she generated great energy from Jack Nicholson, but also went one better by pairing him with a fantastic Diane Keaton.

Her next film, It's Complicated, featured a great performance from Meryl Streep (well, that's expected) but an over the top Alec Baldwin and a series of terrible supporting characters ruined the film.
After a long layoff, she's back, and this time she's dragged more energy out of Robert De Niro than many of his recent performances.
De Niro is great with comedy and he plays it very well throughout.
The humour is not an endless series of 'he's old, he doesn't understand the youngsters and their technology' and they certainly don't try to weave in any romance between him and Hathaway (thank God).
But the jokes are consistent and the plot moves along briskly, and deals with just enough depth to lift it above many films of a similar style.
Of the rest of the cast, Hathaway is excellent, and like De Niro, effortless.
There's a good performance (all be it occasional) from Rene Russo, and the supporting men surrounding De Niro are all fine.
However, Holm feels a bit miscast as the husband.

He suits the role early as the stay at home dad playing with the daughter, however, in the final act of the movie, he doesn't bring enough depth to the character to hold the weight the scenes required.

Hathaway and De Niro will raise your spirits, and the film's feminist angle - while not particularly fleshed out - remains a refreshing touch.
The Intern is a movie with a premise that hooked me from the first time I saw a trailer.
The idea of 70-year-old Robert De Niro working as an intern at a young up-and-coming business run by Anne Hathaway was great.
Thankfully they didn't spend much time on explaining the logic of why they were seeking employees that old, so it just got things rolling early without too much exposition.
This is where the movie got my hopes up.
It cut right to his hiring pretty quickly, but then it took almost half the movie before De Niro started to have any significant interactions with Hathaway.
I thought the movie would be a great look at how the wisdom of our elders can be a valuable tool in the modern workplace, but he doesn't provide as much guidance as I was expecting.
There were certainly moments that met my expectations, but they were few and far between.
I actually started to wonder why Hathaway's character grew attached to him at all.
I also felt they spent way too much time with Hathaway's family, which was the weaker aspect of the movie.
I think I know what Nancy Meyers was trying to do (talk about how people still tend to belittle strong working women) but that wasn't the message I expected to be delivered by The Intern.
Also, because she intended to focus on that message, it would undermine her strength as a character if De Niro did anything of significance to "save" her.
So the theme she was striving for ended up undermining the main premise of the plot.
It's a sweet enough movie to watch, and I enjoyed parts of it, but it fell short of my expectations.

DeNiro is a bastion of old masculinity, an embodiment of the middle class america of youre and he becomes endearing to the millennial hipster crowd by sheer can-do-ness and seriousness.
Kids these days amirite?
And in that process he becomes a surrogate masculine figure for quirky, overworked, overachieving start-up founder Hathaway.
And this is where the politics get confusing, at least for me as a man with sympathies for feminism.
Hathaway is a female Steve Jobs: precise, wealthy through her own merits and workaholic.
She is also quite opposed to boys business club masculinity.

But still once she gets DeNiro as an intern she is all about leaning on him as a father figure and an emblem of the father-knows-best men of yore (who knows, for instance that she needs to eat when she doesn't, or that she had too much to drink or knows both on-line advertising/sales AND the streets of Brooklyn better etc.).
DeNiro is the opposite of a manic pixie dream girl, he is a Calm Progressive Dream Grandpa, the intangible but eminently crush-able strong, supportive man that checks all the boxes.
Fortunately, unless you're a critical asshole, this is all not extremely noticeable, because the leads have mad chemistry together.
DeNiro is enjoyable, believable and likeable for the first time in ages and Hathaway is... well great.
She cranks it up to 100 and creates a complex character in work and family life and jives stunnigly well with DeNiro's respectful, helpful grandpa.
The supporting cast of ditzy hipsters is these for a couple of laughs including a rather cringeworthy 'heist' scene that seemed tacked on.
But then again, with the exception of Something's gotta give (and even there the humour wobbles) director meyers never could do comedy and was over and over saved by the strength of the cast.
Except in What women want cause fuck that movie.
So, yeah, the Intern is appealing and endearing, even if it misfires quite a bit.
But if you want to see DeNiro in a good role or Hathaway once more, go see it.
10/10 would recommend.
Just excellent all around.
The acting was superb, and the story pulled at every emotion a bit.

Thanks to the chemistry of the two superstars in The Intern, DeNiro and Hathaway, The Intern is a likable movie.
The story itself is flawed, yes, but DeNiro and Hathaway have excellent chemistry and create two great characters.
What I enjoy, when films can do it right, is when there's no "villain."
There are flawed people through the movie so writer Nancy Meyers is able to create dilemma, but nobody is a "bad guy."
Her films are like this and she's mostly successful.
Any movie like this is going to have a problem if the run-time is over 2-hours (The Intern is 2:01).
There's just no need for it.
Also, the awkward way the The Intern had Jules (Hathaway) deal with Ben (DeNiro) was a snag in the movie.
The errors in the story are ones I wouldn't expect from a writer/director of Nancy Meyers' calibre.
Once this clumsy part to the story is past, The Intern really takes off.
With an 80% audience score, which is excellent, I'd say The Intern is definitely worth a rent.

The Intern is directed and written by Nancy Meyers, and it stars Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway in a comedy film about Ben Whittaker (Robert De Niro) who's a senior and wants to apply for a job.
So when he come across a program that seniors would become interns from a fashion company, he wants to apply for it, got the job, and now work as an intern for the CEO of About the Fit.
It has been a while since I've watched a Nancy Meyers film, and when I saw this film on HBO, I thought, why not, and just record it so I can watch it later.
What I didn't realize is that I didn't expect this movie to be really great, just thought it was just there.
Robert De Niro is terrific in this, probably his best in a long time as I haven't seen this type of character that he plays before, and he does it pretty well.

Anne Hathaway does a good job of the character that she plays, and the chemistry between them is actually the best part of the film as they are pretty much having a friendship with no hints of of a romance, which I'm glad they didn't do that.
The writing by Nancy Meyers is pretty interesting in a way that I'm invested in the characters who are developed enough for me to find them likable and memorable.
There were some parts that I was worried that it was going to be a big deal, but it goes by short and sweet, which I was relieved and I liked how it was handled.
It's really funny, and the drama moments work really well.
There were some plot elements that really did not need to be there, even if it is hilarious, and there were some predictable moments in there.
But with all of that said, I clearly underestimate The Intern, and I'm glad that I did.

Not to confuse with 2013 Fox's The Internship, this similar type of drama without a ship behind feels more promising, funny but not ridiculous and thoughtful which one could have expected through its poster.

The story delivers something fresh, a creative idea of senior citizen internship program to present the cross-generation relationship, events that are commonly occur in daily working life and how important is the experience of the elderly to inspire the younger generation.

The film moves in a smooth pace, filled with nice musics and inspiring scores, along with a gentle spirit that attracts audiences to spend time following the amusing characters for about 120 minutes but a little bit upset by the rushing second half and too unrealistic perfection on its ending.

However, the warm, charming and charismatic chemistry between De Niro and Hathaway is the sweetest and most beautiful part of the film to enjoy which makes us believe that we can manage well both career and family life.

This is a charming movie with some tender moments and some witty humour at times.
The story affirms and celebrates values of decency and good manners along with the contribution that older people can make to society.
Anne Hathaway has real screen presence as the young CEO who has to overcome her prejudices of having an older intern.
It's also good that Robert de Niro is back on screen in a decent role.
While the direction loses its focus occasionally, this is an enjoyable, easy-to-watch comedy with some gentle critique of aspects of modern society and good chemistry between its lead actors.

"The Intern" is a sure-fire hit for adults of all ages.
Offering plenty of laughs and smiles, the film tosses in several heavy doses of reality and sadness-all mixed into an otherwise straight-forward storyline.
De Niro brings the calmness and demeanor of a James Bond around an office water cooler.
His charisma and gentle manners takes us back to a slower, more enjoyable life and pace that can still work in today's nonstop world.
The always delightful Hathaway captivates us with her wide-range of acting tools.
Together, the team of Hathaway and De Niro combine to give audiences an extremely enjoyable and warm big-screen experience.

Rating: Fine I know sometimes the word fine has a negative connotation, but this is definitely the real definition: "choice, excellent, or admirable".
I really enjoyed this movie from beginning to end with only some slight missteps along the way.
The strongest aspect of this film is the reality of it.
Throughout the story I felt that this characters will part of the real world.
And when you believe that the premise behind the movie becomes the clear focus and provides great insight to society while telling an engaging story.
The difference between the older generation of Robert De Niro and the younger workforce led by Anne Hatheway introduces just enough to make you question the modern day.

While mentioning the actors we can applaud them because they did a wonderful job of getting us to care about the characters, it is nice to see De Niro throwing himself into a role, even if the character is mostly laid-back yet still charming.
And of course Anne Hatheway remains to be one of the best actresses out there, and stunningly gorgeous.
The movie is not without faults when it attempts to juggle a few too many story-lines and characters that do not always follow through to a satisfying conclusion.
In the same vein some of those pieces mismatch the genuine lived in feel and just stand out as silly moments.
Still this is an enjoyable tale and y'all should definitely check it out if the premise looks intriguing to you.

But the legend himself, Robert De Niro, all geared up to play for humor and heart, is at his most charming and beguiling.

De Niro is Ben Whittaker, 70, a retired widower hired as an intern for a Brooklyn e-commerce fashion house run by Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), a work-obsessed wife and mother who can't even think of what she could learn from an old guy until, well, she does.
Writer-director Nancy Meyers (Something's Gotta Give, It's Complicated) and De Niro make it all go down way easy.
This is an easy movie to like - what's not to, with DeNiro (self deprecating humor) and Hathaway (strong yet vulnerable) as the leads.

The Intern: A Perfectly Heartwarming film, and much much more!
The Intern' is run-of-the-mill heartwarming drama about a woman who makes good with an idea, a laptop, and a chair.
It's the American Dream, you know.?
?Through a set of convoluted occurrences, the boss of an internet shopping company, thirty something Jules, takes on "senior interns" (people over 65) to work in her company.
That leads to a series of 'surprises.'
One surprise is that the old intern 'Ben' (De Niro) is not incompetent.
Shocking!
They learn that old people have something to contribute.
How heartwarming!
And the audience is shocked to learn that young folks don't have all the answers.
Ben is so willing to help, you wonder where he has been all your life.
All the heartwarming drama nearly gave me a heart attack.
Suffice to say, it's predictable.
The film's efforts to tell a unique story fall flat.
It is apparent that this is a star vehicle with a goal of making bank on the combination of De Niro and Hathaway on the screen.
It doesn't bomb because of the expertise of the two stars, but the plot drags it down.
Ben, a goodhearted seventy-year-old retired divorcee, teaches the youngsters in the office new tricks.
He effortlessly makes friends of everyone in Jules' office and knows exactly what everyone needs.
He is the perfect intern.
At one point of the movie, Jules (Hathaway) asks Ben (De Niro), "Why do you always say the perfect thing?"
Why, indeed.
He's too perfect and he brings no conflict to the table; in fact, he's boring.
Sure, his homespun logic and chill advice are clever, and it is too obvious.
But it is heartwarming.
The overworked self-made women (Jules) doesn't have time for anyone, especially herself, as she tries to keep her company running.
But she's a loving and patient woman who adores her daughter, Paige.
Her husband is the 'stay at home dad of the year.'
Even when things go awry in their marriage, it's so damn heartwarming that it makes angels vomit.
Age barriers are overcome through clever, pat answers.
A whiter-than-white cast stand insulated in a web of banal first-world problems.
The major conflict in the film comes down to control and self actualization.
Sure, in the context of Jules' life, it's important.
For a movie, it's not terribly compelling.
I'm surprised the film turned out as entertaining as it did.
It helps that they didn't throw in a last minute cancer, house burning down or earthquake.
That is the rankest type of plot device and I am happy that I haven't seen that in recent dramas and romances.
In the film, it's all upper middle-class white America all the time, as if we were in the 50s, Leave it to Beaver version of Brooklyn, NY.
I haven't seen a film this white since 'Boyhood.'
Then again, an online vendor that sells clothing to "housewives" might attract mainly white college educated employees.
Moreover, the film has to ignore class conflict in the 21st century in order to make Jules' problems at all dramatic.
In the context of the world, her issues are trite and she is a pathetic whiner, type A personality who thinks her life amounts to a hill of beans in this crazy world.
?Overall, it's handled by the actors: Rental For all the blandness, the two stars pull of a decently entertaining film.

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse Burleson 2015's The Intern (my latest review) is great.
There I said it.
This is feel-good, cotton candy people.
You stagger out of the theater with a sense of giddiness.
Then you say to yourself, "wow, that's a real film".
Its lead (Mr. Robert De Niro) has never been more likable.

You wouldn't even know it's the same guy who played psychotics (Taxi Driver, Cape Fear), hardened criminals (Heat, The Family), and ornery grandpappys (Meet the Fockers, Little Fockers) some years ago.
Crazy.
With his co- star being Anne Hathaway (also very likable), screen chemistry is indeed abounding.
A friendship develops between their characters producing an inner wallop.
Now in all honesty, I don't ever cry at the movies.
Here, I got the sniffles and that's saying something.
As directed by Nancy Meyers, "Intern" has one of her trademarks written all over it.
That would be the adage of well-off people having problems (in relationships) that aren't life-threatening.
You could also include the notion of two protagonists sharing scenes and being worlds apart in age (remember Keanu Reeves and Diane Keaton in Something's Gotta Give?).
So yeah this flick is cutesy at times.
Yeah it ends with a level of uncertainty (talking about cinema makes way for interpretation you know).
Yeah it starts off sort of predictable.
Yeah it has some nitwit, supporting characters and yes, there's a cringe-worthy boner gag (don't ask).
But look closer and stick around for the full two hours (despite what other critics thought, the overlength didn't bother me).
There's something deeper than what was advertised in the trailer.

Here's a hint and spoiler alert (warning): The husband of Hathaway's persona (Matt Ostin played by Anders Holm), isn't much of a shade and doesn't hold the screen until his revelatory stance hits you up in the third act.
Talk about a plot diversion in a so-called, mawkish comedy.

Shot near the perky side of Brooklyn, New York and featuring an email heist referencing caricatures from Ocean's Eleven, The Intern is a romcom without the "rom", a centerpiece sledgehammering facets of old age (you could also throw in older people's spar with newer technology).
The story starts off without a struggle or conflict before later kicking into high gear.
You have Ben Whittaker (De Niro), a widower who just wants some higher form of human interaction.
He's retired, he's traveled the world, he hangs out at Starbucks, and when walking down the street, he gets hit on by weird women (Linda Lavin from the TV show Alice, who'd thunk it).
Sadly, this is not enough for him.
The solution: He signs up for a community outreach program in which seniors intern for thirtysomething boss, Jules Ostin (Hathaway).
Ostin owns a Internet fashion company, built from the ground up.
She's initially reserved, conservative, and off-putting.
And her first impression of Ben is that he's too observant not to mention a little invading.
Then things change.
As time marches on, De Niro's Ben and Hathaway's Jules form a wonderful kinship.
They eventually turn into best friends.
Refreshingly, it was great to see two Oscar winners thrive at the top of their game.
When they're on screen (together or separate), "Intern" is a real winner.
When they aren't in frame (which hardly ever happens), the material is sadly, a little sluggish and kind of hackneyed.
Anyway, if you've recently watched The Internship (2013), you'll somewhat be reminded of The Intern.
Both films start off similar yet the latter ascends to something much greater.
Bottom line: Chalk up another round of effective, sentimental goo courtesy of the veritable Nancy Meyers.
I'm gonna go with a rating of 3 and a half stars on this one.
Of note: De Niro's Ben Whitaker has a need to fill a void in his life.
He's retired with money yet is bored.
That's why he takes on the task of working in e-commerce territory.
De Niro the actor, well he seems to be filling that same void (Bobby's rich but still likes to appear in three to four movies a year).
With endeavors like Grudge Match, Last Vegas, New Year's Eve, and 2013's Killing Season, he hasn't been too picky about his projects.
The Intern thankfully, reverses this trend.
Mucho "De Niro" justified!

The Intern is about fitting in with the times while maintaining a certain humbleness before those who have what is irreplaceable: life experience.

The Intern is directed by Nancy Meyers and stars the great Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway.
This is the first Nancy Meyers film I am seeing and I was pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed the intern.

The Intern is a sweet feel good comedy that starts off as a movie showcasing the differences in lifestyle,mannerisms and characteristics between the current generation and the older generation before heading towards the more drama heavy side of things with De Niro guiding Anne Hathaway in some of her life choices.
De Niro is fantastic in this film and his character is so likeable.
Anne Hathaway is great as well and the chemistry between the two is the main reason why this movie is so damn entertaining.
De Niro's interactions with some of the other younger interns are also hilarious and had the audience laughing out loud.
My only issue with the intern is that there are some unnecessary scenes which don't really add much to the movie and hamper the pace making it feel slightly long.
The Intern is definitely worth watching when you are in the mood for something light hearted.

Out of the long list of films I had planned to go and see, The Intern was nowhere close to being on that list, but when my girlfriend felt the need to tag along to the movies with me and adamantly suggested that we take a break from the norm and try one of "her movies", I went against my better judgment and begrudgingly agreed, little did I know she would choose a film that was finally watchable.

I say watchable because this movie is basically a sequel to The Devil Wears Prada but without Meryl Streep, but instead plugging Robert De Niro in the Anne Hathaway role and allowing Hathaway to play the Miranda role without the attitude and confrontation, thus making this movie a boring heartwarming work place character piece without the drama.
This film comes across as just a movie to fill a slot during a slow weekend where no prominent films that people take seriously were debuting.

The pacing is slow and the characters are bland to the point that you don't care about whatever benign conflict that they try to interject into the plot to give the story purpose and I was just hoping that the movie would hurry up and reach its obvious conclusion so I could leave.
The casting was about the only thing that they got right with this movie.
The plot was basically a mash up of The Internship and The Devil Wears Prada but without the witty one liners or eccentric bosses which leaves you wondering what's the point.

At best this is about on par with a made for tv Lifetime movie which pretty much means I am not in the demographic that this movie was trying to target, but if your into that very mellow drama kind of films then I would say it is better than most and worth you checking out
A Nancy Meyers film has no place for gritty realism so with that in mind, this is a safe and nice film that's slightly overlong, oftentimes sitcom-y and does exactly what it says on the tin.
Lack of surprises aside, De Niro and Hathaway gave it their best to give the flimsy material some weight and drama in the third act but it was never meant to be.
The takeaway here is that the technology obsessed youths can learn a few things from seniors who've got the experience of life.
How delightful but hardly profound!
The script could've been written by your hip grandma who has managed to master whatsapp - give it an extra star rating if you are into that sort of escapist nonsense.

This movie has been promoted as a comedy but its really little more that a 'chick flick' designed to propagate the idea that 'you can have it all'.
Jules has a successful startup company, a loving and supportive husband and a beautiful daughter but her commitment to her career results in problems at home.
The company decided to develop a 'Senior Intern' who, over time, becomes like a father to her.
With the wisdom of Solomon he guides her through various problems.
In true Hollywood fashion this 70 year old middle-class guy just happens to have spent his career as VP of publishing company (don't all middle class people retire from upper level management?).

When the problems at home begin to take its toll he, in true feminist fashion, convinces here that even though she has little time for her family its not her fault and that she needs to be "true to herself".
I guess that means she should put herself ahead of her family and others.
Overall, a 'feel good' movie with good acting and a story line that does entertain.
Were it not for the obvious sexist theme and absurd message I might rate it higher but because of its heavy political nature I can only rate it 2 stars

"The Intern" is a film starring Robert DeNiro who enters a senior citizen internship program to bring a new dynamic to Anne Hathaway's start-up telecommunications firm.
At first, Hathaway has a hard time warming up to DeNiro but comes to form an affecting, unlikely bond with him.
This film is watchable, but I wasn't sold on the whole new-age generation gap thing.
This film has a lot to say about generation gaps and that older people have to get hip with the current times.
While both are highly competent actors, I thought the dynamic was a bit bizarre, and had their ages not been so vastly different, it might have worked.
Both do solid acting but it doesn't make the relationship any better.
I thought the film was also fleeting and absent a decent score and some interesting dialogue, this film is thoroughly forgettable.
It is very whimsical and doesn't tread any new narrative ground not treaded before.
This is a film meant for simple viewing without any deeper meaning --------------------------------------------------------------- C+

A mildly interesting premise - what would happen if 70 year old Robert De Niro were working for internet startup entrepreneur Anne Hathaway?
At first, very little but the film builds to a nice ending, but with a firm ambition to sell you The Intern 2 too.
61 year old Rene Russo is the love interest for De Niro, The rest of the characaters are not really explored serving variously as foils for De Niro or Hathaway.
Some of the plot is implausible - how does De Niro solve an IT problem that the Internet startup boss cannot?
Mostly seeing this film reminded me of the character De Niro played in "Once Upon A Time In America", The 70 year old De Niro looks very look the aged gangster Noodles Aaronson .
But Nancy Meyers is no Sergio Leone.
This is an altogether gentler film, sentimental in parts,
I really enjoyed this film from start to finish.

The writing is fairly weak and the characters are a bit exaggerated, but the production design is great.
All in all, "The Intern" is a well acted, average movie that your grandmother will love.

Too entertaining to warrant a senior skip day thanks to its leads, The Intern takes a softball approach to its promising premise but moviegoers can't help but love the chemistry behind this office non-romance.

Just like with any other Nancy Meyers comedy, moviegoers get introduced to a work roster of goofy but lovable supporting characters and an overall story that feels fresh despite ultimately plucking the strings of predictability.
Oh, some unsuspected roadblocks might surprise you but the final trajectory's always pretty clear.
What makes The Intern unique so far as this writer-director's CV goes, however, is the age of the female lead.
Her ensemble work aside (The Holiday), Meyers tends to stay within her actual range (Diane Keaton, Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated).
In dotcom founder Jules, however, we get a mega successful glass ceiling-breaking online store founder who's got a family to boot.

Far from a caricature, she's also a spread-too-thin boss who invests in a camaraderie and loyalty-building environment for her employees (on-site masseuse, lax dress code, office bike riding), as well as no patience for her mother and not enough time for her hubby.
In Anne Hathaway, Meyers finds one of the only actresses capable of coloring in and outside of her lines to a brilliant degree.
You come to love Jules, just as you do the title character.
Since committing to comedy nearly full time (Analyze This, Meet the Parents), Robert De Niro has gotten warmer and has gotten the audience to warm to him more as an Everyman.
Notice that those successful flicks listed in the last sentence don't require much suspension of disbelief for buying the actor outside of his usual tough guy wheelhouse.
With The Intern, however, we get a full drawn portrait of a still-vital retiree helping Jules through some crucial work and life changes.

Hathaway and De Niro work so well together and their personalities complement so perfectly at this juncture in their lives that you wonder how they would have melded if she got dropped into one of his films during the height of his H'wood run (Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Goodfellas).

In this PG-13-rated comedy from writer/director Nancy Meyers (The Parent Trap, What Women Want), a 70-year-old widower (DeNiro) becomes bored with retirement and takes a senior intern position at an online fashion site created and run by a much younger woman (Hathaway).
Beyond Hathaway and De Niro's compatibility, however, their remains some problems with this twosome's vehicle.
Fluffy is the word for The Intern, which could have made some riper social commentary as to the actual viability of pension-aged Americans in the workplace and old vs. new approaches to business.
Oh, Meyers bats around such discussion a bit but she seems to be wearing an oven mitt, only lightly touching on these talking points.
Still, even the color-by-numbers moments make for an enjoyable office dynamic.
Bottom line: High Pension

I really enjoyed "The Intern," but have a quibble about its treatment of middle aged & senior women.
I loved the interaction between DeNiro & the younger men (although he never seemed to get them to want to shave--hey guys ZZ Top is right---every girl is crazy about a sharp-dressed man!)

I rated this move 3 1/2 for two reasons: the way older women are depicted (as "raging bitches"--Jules Mom--\ complete buffoons--the intern who couldn't drive--or the pushy, lonely one-night stand--Linda Lavin's character).
Older women can also be as suave, well-dressed, & knowledgeable as older men.
I'm tired of seeing women my age used as nothing more than comic relief.
Having Rene Russo as the sole older woman who is sane doesn't balance out the other 3.
I also felt that the movie didn't need a really late (story-wise) plot twist.
Overall, an enjoyable movie.
DeNiro's performance shows he can do comedy as well as he can do drama & I didn't want to kill Anne Hathaway 5 minutes in, so she did fine too.
The young actress playing her daughter is adorable & I would be crushing on the other men in the picture if only they'd shave, tuck in their shirts, & dress sharply.

After reading all of the so-so reviews of this movie, I had gauged my expectations, and was delighted to see a fun, ironic and (at times) a film with deep insights_x0097_especially into what amount to Horatio Alger stories with a woman playing the head of a start-up dot com.
The idea that "she can do it all"-- family, mom, wife and company head is not so much challenged (any more than it would be for a man), but placed into focus.
In the 1950s-60s, the nose-to-the-grindstone man in the gray flannel suit was seen as a person whose family was ignored at the expense of attention to his family.

This film is refreshing in that it recognizes that concentrating on work over family is not a mortal sin and any problems with spouse and child cannot to blamed on the Type A personality in the family regardless of gender.
Robert De Niro is perfect.
At 70 he is retired and bored, but he doesn't come across either as a fuddy-duddy Luddite or a swinging grandpa.

Keeping in mind that the De Niro character was in his 30s when personal computers came on the scene in early 1980s and just 40 when the Mac was released in 1984, computer technology in the home and office is not exactly new.
Getting used a new type of interface or program does take time, but it is no longer the mystery box it was at one time to the older generation.
This is a much more intelligent (and fun) movie than I expected; so, if you plan to go 1) lower your expectations 2) pay attention, and 3) enjoy!

This is probably the third best Nancy Myers movie I've seen (Behind "It's Complicated" and "Something's Gotta Give").

Myers is exceptional at attracting top rate talent to her movies (See, DeNiro and Hathaway for this one; Meryl Streep, Alec Baldwin and Steve Martin for "Complicated" and Jack Nicholson and Diane Keaton for "Give.")
She also gets excellent performances from the talent.
The story casting and story telling fall down a bit on this one.
Myers seems not really to know how to get a story to the end, a failing the other two movies had as well.
That said, you will greatly enjoy the relationship between DeNiro and Hathaway.
DeNiro's relationship with some younger male interns (young enough to be his grandsons) is also very funny.
Of course, in Myers world, even the "poor" people aren't really poor, but you know that going in.

The Intern is the definition of feel good cinema, I can guarantee you that throughout the film you will be smiling, and there so many instances the film is just so heart touching.But what really works for the film is the lead cast of Robert D'Niro who is only getting better with age, and Anne Hathaway who is epitome of really beauty.
There chemistry is just perfect.
Story wise the film talks about a 70 year old man named Ben, he is officially retired, and is a widower.

After traveling the globe for awhile, he is back home and hates thinking about living at home all day,so he keeps himself busy all the time, sometimes he goes to visit his kids, or goes to starbucks etc.
Until one day he learns of a opportunity to become a senior Intern at a online fashion company, and he pounces at the opportunity.
He eventually gets the job, and meets the owner of the company Jules.
Jules is a young but busy women running a company by herself, and she has a family which her stay at home husband runs.
How the not so tech savy senior intern Ben comes into Jules's life and helps her in her journey is what the film is about.
Acting wise, I must say Robert D'Niro steals the show, his character is so well written, and he embodies the traits of being a classy gentleman wonderfully.
Anne Hathaway looks so beautiful, but more importantly gives a superb,mature act.The rest of supporting cast has done a great job, and is casted perfectly.
The Intern is a movie made for a mature audience, and while the film has many laughs, the films undertone meanings are what really win your heart.
I truly loved how the film dealt with the message of women empowerment in such a fresh but beautiful way.
And one of the films major assets was how the character of Robert D'Niro was written, how even after being 70 he is still enjoying his life to the fullest, and how he is a true gentleman.

I mean for me the film really didn't have any negatives other than the place slackened a bit towards the end Overall The Intern is not a pathbreaking film, but the film truly lived up to its amazing trailer.Its nice to see a film deal with real life situations, in a beautiful, light manner and not be so serious and sad.
Its a film I throughly enjoyed without any hiccups, and its a film I highly recommend, you get your tickets worth in just seeing the chemistry between D'Niro and Hathaway.

Sometimes you don't need a film to try and change the world, make bold political or societal statements or even be shocking.
Sometimes it's good enough to be an audience member who can just sit back, relax and enjoy the show... and smile.
That's the kind of movie you get when you sit down to enjoy "The Intern" (PG-13, 2:01).
Robert DeNiro plays the title character, a retired 70 year-old widower who has become bored with his life.
After 40 years in the business of printing telephone books and then losing his beloved wife of 42 years, he did his best to adjust to his new life, and it worked - for a while.
He traveled the world and engaged in a wide variety of physical and intellectual pursuits to keep himself occupied, but it wasn't enough.
When walking the streets of his native Brooklyn, he sees a flyer for a senior intern program at a young, but burgeoning internet clothing company.
Ben feels that learning more about technology and working with young people feels like just the challenge he needs to occupy his mind and his time.

He applies, via a terrific self-made video (the company's requirement), and sits through a series of amusing interviews with company employees young enough to be his grandchildren... and he gets the internship.
Ben ends up working directly for the company's very capable, but over-extended founder, played by Anne Hathaway.
The senior intern program was her idea, but Jules is initially hesitant to deal with Ben personally on a daily basis.
She's a perfectionist who's constantly on the go.
She's difficult to work for and she knows it.
She loves and respects all 220 of her employees, but her motto might as well be "If you want something done right, you have to do it yourself."
Yet, it's hard to resist Ben's earnestness, strong work ethic and wise, calming presence.
After a little awkwardness as Ben and Jules both try to figure out how he can best serve his new boss, he ends up becoming her driver.

In this capacity, he gets to know Jules' stay-at-home husband (Anders Holm), their precocious, but adorable young daughter (JoJo Kushner) and, most importantly, Jules herself, in all her earnestness, anxiety and vulnerability.
It turns out that, at this stage of the game, Jules needs Ben's wisdom and support more than she'd be willing to admit - to him or herself.
Her company is growing so fast and she's so hands-on that one of her assistants (Andrew Rannells) tells her that the investors would like to see her take on a CEO.
This would lighten her load, but it would also mean effectively giving control of her company to someone else.

She half-heartedly interviews people to be her potential boss, not sure that this is the best move, but wanting to do right by her employees and her marriage, which is starting to suffer due to the demands of her very busy schedule.

In the midst of all this, Ben becomes a sounding board and occasional advice dispenser for Jules, a very helpful co-worker and kind of pseudo uncle to a small group of the company's young employees (played by Adam DeVine, Zack Pearlman, Jason Orley and Christina Scherer) and a possible love interest for the company's full-time in-house masseuse (Rene Russo).
Ben is at the story's center, but it's the great mix of interesting characters and subplots that makes this movie so worthwhile.
DeNiro has rarely been more pleasant to watch, or Hathaway so winning, as they lead an ensemble cast that complements each other wonderfully.
Nancy Myers' amusing and purposeful script and direction highlight the virtues of women making the most of their lives, but never hits us over the head with her message.
Jules is simply a modern woman who's very likeable and subtly inspiring.

A scene in which some of Jules' employees break the law to help her with a pressing personal problem is fun, but seems misplaced, and the resolutions to some of the story's conflicts seem a little trite, but, overall, this is simply a delightful film that I'd recommend to anyone.
"The Intern" isn't perfect, but is definitely worth having around.
The Intern is a simple, predictable movie--an old gentleman who wants a life meets a young person who is lost, and they eventually sort things out with some tears on the side.
However, that's one of the major factor that made me like this movie.
It's charming, cute, makes you laugh, and these things never get old.

I know this might get some criticism for its cheesiness and its simplicity, but it's a good drama movie that makes you smile (probably what it's meant to do) and, honestly, I don't really expect much more in this area.
It does its job, most movies fail to do so; maybe not a 'great' movie, but a good one.

Ah, Nancy!

For years now (in films like¬†"What Women Want,"¬†"The Holiday" and¬†"It's Complicated"),¬†you have been writing and directing films that put women front and center - professional women, with impressive credentials¬†- only to undermine the power of that image¬†with a strange brand of (unintentional?)
misogyny.
On the surface, your films look, at first,¬†like¬†feminist confections, but then you always end up¬†trafficking in the worst kind of feminine stereotypes.
No matter what their strengths and achievements, your protagonists are inevitably emotional, irrational, and in need of a man to make things right.
Even a career woman needs love, no matter what the cost, you always remind us.
At least in¬†"Something's Gotta Give"¬†- my favorite of yours - you bring the man down a peg as much as the woman.
How broadminded of you ...

In¬†"The Intern," Meyers¬†turns things around (a bit), taking the perfect man and turning him into good ole Dad - or, at least, a father figure - in the form of Robert De Niro, who once wowed the world with his kinetic energy in films like¬†"Taxi Driver," and now spends his time mugging for the camera in films like¬†"Last Vegas"¬†(and¬†"The Intern").
De Niro plays 70-ish Ben, who was once an executive at a phonebook (remember those?)
company and is now a retired widower in need of something to fill his days.
When he sees a flyer advertising a "senior intern" program at a local (Brooklyn, NY) e-commerce company, he jumps at the chance to apply, just to have something to do.

The movie opens with Ben recording his application video, intercut with a montage of his present-day life, which includes a trip to San Francisco to see his son and grandchildren and, back home, an awkward exchange with a local widow - played by a very funny, if under-utilized, Linda Lavin (of "Alice" fame) - who has her own plan for how to cure Ben's loneliness.
Lo and behold, the company - an internet fashion retailer called "About the Fit" - calls Ben in, and he gets the gig.
If it all seems a bit easy, it is, helped along by the usual easy-listening soundtrack¬†of composer Theodore Shapiro ("We're the Millers").
Still,¬†De Niro, hamminess aside, is pleasant enough to watch, and there are a few gags that score.
So what is a "senior intern" to do?
Well, no one knows, really, least of all the founder and CEO of the company, 30-ish Jules - played by Anne Hathaway ("Interstellar") with her usual spunk - but Ben is assigned to her, anyway.

She ignores him, until Ben makes himself so indispensable to the entire office (he's that just that kind of guy) that she just has to take notice, and before long he is driving her to and from work, watching her kid, and spending time in her (amazing) Brooklyn brownstone¬†with house-husband (sorry, "stay-at-home dad," as Jules corrects Ben) Matt - a very forgettable Anders Holm ("Unexpected").
And why does Jules - successful internet mogul that she is - need and respond to this new older masculine presence?

Well, it turns out that all is not perfect at home or at work: she never sees hubby, and when she does, they're both too tired to talk or get it on; she can't spend even the minimal time with her daughter that she should; and her investors think she should take on a "real" (male) CEO to allow her to work less and focus on the company's vision.
Since what we see on the screen kind of supports these facts and assessments of her performance (maybe not the male CEO part), it's hard not to agree that, yes, she needs help.
And with Ben so competent, he's just the fellow to save the day.
It's all relatively harmless, and occasionally touching and funny, but all to often it's just a little regressive for my taste.

Ben even finds a more appropriate - for Meyers' taste - love interest in the form of the beautiful office masseuse played by Rene Russo (Nightcrawler), charming as ever, and, of course, 11 years younger than Ben (Lavin's character is just too old and pushy).

If the film were 30 minutes shorter and with all of the¬†exposition cut out - Ben to Jules, "You can do it on your own" - it might be more watchable and I might forgive it its faults in the breezy rush to the finish line.
But so often, it's a bit of¬†a slog.
Then again, if you've loved every other Nancy Meyers film, then you might be used to her aesthetic and not mind any of it.
If so, then go see it in the full confidence that the director is true to her own legacy.
The Guardian's Jordan Hoffman writes that The Intern is a "chain of predictable sequences shot in a flat manner."

Father of the Bride 1 & 2, The Parent Trap, What Woman Want and Something's Gotta Give.
Some of my favorite feel-good/rom-com films from the past.
They all have one thing in common, they're directed by the great Nancy Meyers.
Meyers is one of the director's that every time she releases a film I'm always super excited to check it out because it could become a Nancy Meyers classic like the films listed above.
Is this a Nancy Meyers classic?
Yes and No.
First off I must start by saying I enjoyed this film.
It's a funny, charming and breezy.
The performances by De Niro, Hathaway and Rene Russo are great, and kudos to Meyers for bringing out a solid performance out of De Niro that shows that he can still be great when he tries.
The film also looks nice and boasts a fun score that's straight out of the '90s.
It was heartfelt, inspiring and surprising at times and then at other times the film gets lost tonally and suffers "at times" because of it.
There's something so great about seeing a film that has a strong female lead and showcases female empowerment in such an honest and relatable way.
Also a film that shows that no matter your age you never lose your value.

Even though the film veers off its familiar but enjoyable path from time-to-time, and I'm sorry Workaholics fans but Anders Holm was so miscast and delivered the worst performance I've probably seen all year.
And also the ending is so abrupt and story lines are left in limbo and never wrapped up.

SO, besides a few glaring negatives and some major and minor bumps in the road this is still an enjoyable at times and I can see certain audience members being very moved and uplifted by it especially if they can relate to the characters.

Also, the film introduces JoJo Kushner in her first ever theatrical movie role and she just might be the cutest child actor ever that had great chemistry and line delivery, I'm sure we'll be seeing more from her in the future.
Overall, I'll just barely give THE INTERN a 6 out of 10.
It's a decent matinee film and if you're a Nancy Meyers fan there will be enough familiarity there to enjoy.
Just don't pay too much for it and expect a Nancy Meyers classic and you'll be film.

This is a typical Nancy Meyers film.

Basic plot you can probably guess from the trailer: DeNiro comes in on the plot contrivance of an older intern program, and ends up helping Hatheway overcome her stress from running her company and trying to maintain her family life with a stay-at-home dad, with the main conflict being whether or not she'll hire an experienced CEO to help run the company.
What follows is often amusing albeit a pretty standard plot, which is reasonably well acted, and charming enough that you can probably tell if you'll like the movie just from the trailer.
Now, about that emphasis: two elements of this film made me cringe, and I'm not talking about the occasional joke that didn't work for me.
The first is that at one point DeNiro and some of the other interns commit a felony, with Hatheway's knowledge and endorsement, in order to save her some embarrassment from her mother.
Is this supposed to show she's competent at running her company?
The mother character is completely superfluous to the plot; she's only there to be a nag on the phone, is never seen, and could have easily been written out of the plot.

The second I won't get into too much detail about, but suffice to say it's presented as being empowering to Hatheway but instead came off, to me, as trite, cliche, and disempowering and playing to stereotypes.
In other words: typical Nancy Meyers.
Ugh.
If that bothers you less than me, then you may have fun with this.
Personally, those bits that bothered me could have been cut or reshaped, giving a shorter runtime (2 hours is pushing it for what is essentially a comedy), leading to a slightly above middling score.

When I first heard about this concept, I was intreged and when I watched the first trailer, I was actually excited to see this film.
When I got a chance to go and watch the movie four days before it came out, I jumped at the chance and I'm glad I did.
This film was so charming.
It shows that even though they may be a difference in generation, there are some things that we can relate to, young and old.
It had comedic moments which was great and Robert De Niro's character is so likeable.
What I loved the most about this movie is how a women is portrayed.
With films such as Suffurgettes and the last Hunger Games coming out, we need more movies about powerful women.
Anne Hataways character always talks about how hard it is to be a women in the business world.
People don't take you or your job too seriously.
They also think that women can't run a business.
This is something that is very important for me.
I always try to break that stereotype and do something that I love whilst not letting my gender define me.
It's hard at times but I get by.
I love that De Niro's characters doesn't care about gender as well.
He always cares about the personally.
If the person has the passion or not and if they are good at what they do.
Sometimes, the things that Hathaway's character does have some consequences and can make others insecure which is why she has a great partner in the senior intern.
He advices her on the personal life while she helps in the business and technology life.
In the end, I enjoyed it.

I saw The Intern in avant-premiere at the Ostend Movie Festival in Belgium.
Anne Hathaway is a successful entrepreneur of an e-commerce fashion shop.
Her husband takes care of housekeeping and their child and only gets to see her tired late at night.
Meanwhile De Niro gets hired as a senior trainee at Hathaway's company and offers moral support when Hathaways husband is having an affair.
Although The Intern offers a few good laughs and both De Niro and Hathaway give good acting performances, this is not the good tragic comedy drama it could have been.
The Intern resigns to a simple moral tale: in the movie the husband is the 'bad guy' for having an affair and Hathaway the hero.
Fact is in real life, both are victims of a very competitive society which means in order to be very successful, it often means one needs to neglect one's family.
The Intern tries to be feministic, but in fact Hathaway in order to run her company neglects her husband and child (something men have often been accused for in the last decades).
In stead of using this situation to discuss the impact of having a demanding career on family life, The Intern ends up being a simple good-bad tale.
Never the less The Intern offers nice and easy accessible entertainment in typical Hollywood fashion.
But it's depth is neglectable.

A ladies-friendly and gentle comedy, The Intern is a predictable, unrealistic and overly sentimental delivery which hugely, if not mostly, relies on the presence of its two leading characters.

A so-so melodramatic, feministic story is told in a way which would neither annoy you, nor amaze you, but it would just work fine for a calm lazy evening with your beloved half during the cold winter.
Ben Whittaker (Robert De Niro) is a retired successful businessman who cannot simply enjoy the calm life of being a pensioner and decides to participate in a senior-intern program.
Soon gets assigned to be the assistant to a young founder (Anne Hathaway) of a super successful start-up in the field of online sales.
Slowly, both of them have to learn how to work together, but also to learn to be different persons.

Needless to say, the level of predictability, the lack of any climax in the story development and the completely unrealistic depiction of what the post-modern start-up corporate world is, damage the movie's chances to be taken seriously.

Luckily for director Nancy Meyers, the presence of Anne Hathaway and Robert De Niro and the formidable chemistry between them somehow saves the movie from being a complete flop and actually turns it into something passable.

As a whole, The Intern could have been a much better movie, given the record of Nancy Meyers (Something's Gotta Give), but in the end the flaws in her overall approach towards the story is partially compensated by the actors and the feel good final feeling.
Watchable during a flight or in a cold winter evening with your better half next to you.
DeNiro ages with charm and wit.

THE INTERN Review The Intern is a comedy that everyone can enjoy.
It features refreshingly likeable characters, a charming story, and a lot of gut-busting humor.
This movie is a story of a fish out of water story, of friendship, relationships, working in business, and the challenges and advantages that the classic "age gap" presents.
Strangely, the movie feels like it would be a dime-a-dozen romantic comedy if the two characters were closer in age.
But this is just one way that this film feels fresh as the plot, characters, and situations don't feel overly forced.
There is a mix of old and new that works well here because, as we know, experience never gets old.

In modern Brooklyn Robert De Niro stars as Ben Whitaker who, as a 70 year old widower, chooses in his retirement to work as an intern for Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway) the multitasking founder of a growing internet clothing trying to have success in business and family life.
Over time they come to see each others value more.
Both of the leads are delightfully likable characters and you want them to reach their goals.
Ben's chivalrous and experienced attitude makes him the epitome of the title "oldie but goodie".
Jules is a representation of the new age entrepreneurial business kickstarters who are admired today.
The differences between these two is never uncomfortable and keep the audience hoping to see more of what these two will accomplish.
All of the supporting cast are also interesting and play off of each other remarkably well.

These include Rene Russo (Thor) as the flirtatious maseus, Nat Wolff (Paper Towns) as a manager, Adam Devine (Pitch Perfect) as an outgoing fellow intern who, like in all his other roles, needs to imporve his social skills, Zach Pearlman, Andrew Rannells as Jules' assistant, and Christina Scherer as Jules' secretary.
After this, I really want to see Rannells and Scherer in more quality roles.
The director, Nancy Meyers, scored a home run when casting this movie.
Regardless of one's previous experience in business, it is easy to understand how all of these people relate and what the individual business struggles mean.
The entire narrative feels modern and is perfect for 2015.
As a comedy, the part of the movie that should stand out and make people want to see it is the humor.
In the two hour run time the audience laughed out loud 125 times.
The jokes cover all ranges of topics and are presented through the creative situations, snappy dialogue, and perfectly timed visuals.
But the movie is not simply another attempt to push as many jokes as possible into 2 hours.
As cliche as it sounds, the movie has heart, lots of heart.
Ben, Jules, and the others care for each other.
We learn about Ben's 40+ years with his wife, his life as a retiree, Jule's struggling family life, the other interns' personal struggles, and more.
In some comedies I lose interest in the dramatic moments and am just waiting for another laugh.
But in 'The Intern' the comedy is equally captivating interesting as the more emotional sequences.
The technical aspects also cannot be overlooked.
The production design gave each location a unique and interesting look.
Though his work is frequently such a perfect fit for the scene that it is unnoticed, Theodore Shapiro delivers a whimsical and delightful soundtrack for whatever the tone of the scene requires.
After his most recent work, Shapiro is quickly becoming a respectably accomplished composer for comedy (he is possibly becoming the new Christophe Beck).
There is very little to feel unsatisfied about with the film.
The change in tone is occassionally jarring and I was lost to a few of the jokes.
But other than a few trite criticisms, almost any demographic will come away from this feel good movie smiling.
The Intern' was among my favorite comedies that I have seen in the recent past.
Work place comedies have become so common that one of the most beloved sit com TV series of all time was simply called "The Office".
But here the performances and situations feel fresh with the new twists of the aged intern, family struggles, and contrasting lives.
It demonstrates the value of experience, management, passion, leadership, wit, and carrying a hankerchief (as well as blinking - "Jules hates it when people don't blink").

- A- Nancy Meyer comedy THE INTERN from Warner Bros. Pictures stars Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway, Rene Russo, Adam DeVine, Nat Wolff, Anders Holm, Andrew Rannells, Zach Pearlman, & Christina Scherer and is out in theaters September 25th, 2015.

Robert De Niro rarely disappoints and doesn't here.

But the film - perhaps unwittingly - reveals the ways in which driven businesswomen poison their relationships with spouse, parents, and children, yet nevertheless maintains that Hathaway's character is a victim of sexual stereotyping.
It doesn't wash.
If you kept the same script, but reversed the husband/wife roles feminists would be frothing at the mouth.
As it is, you just end up feeling sorry for the husband, the "rising star in marketing" who gave it all up to be a right-thinking progressive house-husband.

There was no reason why the career woman here - she WAS President of her own company, after all - couldn't have taken her tot to her touchy-feely office after pre-school and no reason why her husband had to sacrifice his own dreams.
Good grief!
What century are they living in!

B When walking into the Intern you should know that this movie won't get oscar buzz, but instead just know that's it's such a fun movie.

The Intern follows this senior citizen that becomes an intern with his boss that's younger than him and as the film goes instead of creating a sappy and akward lover story, we get a brighly developed friendship between Anne Hathaway and Robert de Niro that makes this film funner than sappier.

Again, this is jusf like any Nancy Meyers feel good comedy but what makes this film such a good and enjoyable one is Robert de Neio once again giving such a great performance that his character is so likeable that he is clearly the one that saves this movie.

Also Anne Hathaway was good but not great because in the begginjng she starts out being rude and a cartoony character but as the film goes on, you start to like her because you understand why she acts like that and how well developed her chemistry with Robert de Niro gets.

Problems with this movie are that there are many sub-plots like Anne Hathaway with her family that you don't care about and other sub-plots that are completed and are pointless to the main story of this movie.
Also that the story's structure starts to lose it's focus with it going on different kinds of directions.
Lot's of funny jokes are in this film but also bad ones that keep on going and just make this movie akward.

Also that the conclusion to The Intern starts to drag on when you start to wonder when the film is ever gonna end because it adds so much more content for the sake of making this film longer and just like any feel good comedy, In the end besides those flaws, The Intern won't give you anything new but it's the perfect family movie that will make everyone laugh, think about the film's morals and get entertained by.
Nothing in The Intern is absolutely terrible, it's just a movie that you should go watch with a family and just have fun with it for what it is.

Nancy Meyers' films have a certain formula.
Take a good setup idea, add some of the best star actors and have lots of top technical work like Art Direction, Set Decoration, Costume Design and Cinematography.
By the 2nd Act, start adding the usual rom-com mechanics, schmaltzy music and a heavy dose of sentiment.
By the 3rd Act, throw in some unnecessary slapstick and side stories that go on too long.
End the film with everyone happy, a few more tears while characters learn life lessons, and close with lots of hugging.

This has been the pattern with "What Women Want (Mel Gibson, Helen Hunt)," Something's Gotta Give (Diane Keaton, Jack Nicholson)," "It's Complicated (Meryl Streep, Alec Baldwin)," and now "The Intern (Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway)."
Not an awful way to spend two hours, just a very predictable one.

In this case, the film is worth seeing for Robert De Niro, who has evolved into the genial senior actor of his generation with "Meet The Parents," "Analyze This," and especially "Silver Linings Playbook," which is the best film of his late comic period.
His subtle work and skill with all the other cast remind you of how great an actor he has been for over 40 years.

The Intern is that sentimental comedy drama film that tries to have that heartwarming, feel good outlook as the characters are going through some career challenges.
When it comes to these types of films, they can be predictable.
Very predictable, that when watching these characters going through some struggles with their career and their personal lives.
It is easily foreshadowed that everything will be okay in the end.
The film starts with a 70 year old widower Ben (Robert De Niro), who is always trying to keep himself busy in retirement.
He applies to a senior intern at an online fashion company, who the CEO is Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway).
Jules is an every day busy businesswoman, she is always focused on her work, and tidy when it comes to planning, and having everything done the way she wants it too.
Jules is also trying to maintain her personal life with her daughter and husband Matt.
Her husband takes on the role of a stay home daddy, taking the daughter and participating in all the events with her at school.
Ben assist Jules in her every day work by driving her around, giving advice, and life experience lessons, and also trying to help her out with her daughter.
When Jules is coming across a breaking point of wanting another CEO to take charge of her company that she started.
Jules struggles can be predictable, and the film easily shows that every challenge she is going through will easily be handled.
Ben is like that magical person that shows up, does the entire handy errand work to keep everyone on track.
Sort of like a Mary Poppins ideal person.
Jules personal life that she rarely has with her husband and daughter does open the room that her marriage is not exactly healthy.
When her husband is having an affair, as Jules is almost non existent.
Jules is under pressure, the challenges are not really much of a struggle when solutions were easily given.
Making the ending of her accomplishment with deciding the fate of her career and personal life less awarding than it should.
Anne Hathaway and Rober De Niro were both charming and decent with their performances.

Completely pleasant from beginning to end, there's nothing in The Intern that'll challenge or provoke you...but you know what?
That's okay: too few movies these days mistake 'somber' with 'satisfying' and director Nancy Myers-of Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated fame-is someone who gets that.
Frankly, we could use more filmmakers like her.

"Robert De Niro is back in his comfort zone in this pleasant comedy from Nancy Meyers" Movie Review: The Intern Date Viewed: September 30 2015 Written and Directed By Nancy Meyers (What Women Want, The Holiday, It's Complicated and Something's Gotta Give) Starring: Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway, Rene Russo, Anders Holm, Andrew Rannells, Adam DeVine, Zack Pearlman, Jason Orley, JoJo Kushner, Nat Wolff, Steve Vinovich, Linda Lavin, Celia Weston and Molly Bernard.
Writer and director Nancy Meyers is like a cute little poodle, even though the dog performs the same tricks, she still loves her owner.
Meyers' movies have become comfort food for female audiences.
After making "What Women Want", "Something's Gotta Give" and "It's Complicated", Meyers is back with another female-centric comedy.
"The Intern" is a gentle and funny work-place comedy that works mostly because of the likable chemistry between Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway.
Meyers has finally put Bobby back in his comfort zone after making so many terrible movies (The Big Wedding, Grudge Match, Little Fockers, Last Vegas and The Bag Man).
Robert De Niro plays Ben Whittaker, a widower and retired executive who decides to get back in the working game because nothing much happens in his life anymore.
Even though he is in his 70s, Ben Whittaker decides to become an intern at a fast-growing online fashion company.
Ben is assigned to work with founder and CEO Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), who is at first skeptical about him due to his age.
Eventually, Jules comes to like Ben and she let's him become her chauffeur.
Likeable and reliable, everybody in the work place likes Ben and he gets attracted to Fiona (Rene Russo) who is the in-house massage therapist.
Jules is married to her stay-at-home husband, Matt (Anders Holm) and has a little daughter named Paige (JoJo Kushner).
When Ben is assigned to drive Paige to a kids' birthday, he discovers Matt kissing another woman.
It all indicates that Matt can't hold on to his marriage because Jules is absent all the time due to her being CEO.
"The Intern" is a pleasant and charming comedy from Nancy Meyers.
De Niro and Hathaway have great chemistry together and "The Intern" doesn't have the sitcom feel I saw from the commercials.
It is not great cinema but "The Intern" was sweet enough for me to recommend it.

I was really rooting for this movie going in because I enjoyed Nancy Meyers' previous films Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated, but this movie has some issues.

The first hour of this movie is a mess and worthy of a 2 star review with its cringeworthy "old people are so outdated when it comes to the younger generation's lingo and work process" jokes that just do not land at all.
I may have smiled twice in that first hour.
DeNiro is giving it his all and though some of the dialogue is not good, he does a decent job delivering them.
Hathaway is fine too but also is given a really messy timeline of work ethic that doesn't mesh all together.
The ensemble is filled with great people like Adam Devine, Andrew Rannells, Rene Russo, and a hilarious but small part from Linda Lavin.
Anders Holm who I like didn't really fit his part well and I think they under utilized Rannells and Russo.
The movie starts to get better in the second hour after DeNiro and Hathaway form a bond and work pattern together and have some really touching scenes.

Overall, the first half of this movie needed some serious rewriting because it was as if Nancy Meyers was a 100 year old out of touch woman that just based the young characters off of stereotypes in other movies and it needed to be cut down because it got to its point but never decided to leave it.
We get it.
DeNiro is lonely so he's happy to do any work he can do around the office and Hathaway doesn't want his help.
You don't need to spend an hour trying to explain that to the audience.
The ending is a little abrupt and cleaned things up too fast but it was fine, nothing terrible.
It's a good rental

Irresistible first half, clunky second half Love comedy/drama when done right, have liked some of Nancy Meyers' previous work, Robert De Niro at his best is one of the best actors of the latter half of the century (evidenced in 'Taxi Driver', 'Godfather Part II' and 'Raging Bull') and Anne Hathaway has also given good performances.
So 'The Intern' seemed promising.

The Intern' didn't quite live up to expectations, it could have done more with its timely premise and does have things resolved too easily (the cheating subplot in a nausea-inducing forgiveness/reconsideration speech) and characters written too neatly and cleanly (with Ben being very amiable and irresistibly likable if too perfect, Jules is the only one with any real arc).
At its best though, it is easy to warm to and for the first half it was continual engagement that didn't demand too much but did what it said on the tin.
What makes 'The Intern' work is the two leads and their chemistry together.

De Niro is just a joy in one of his best performances in recent years, while Hathaway is a charming high-flyer with good comic timing, succeeding in allowing character growth to a potentially problematic character.
Their chemistry, for such an unorthodox pairing, is so natural and grows warmer without doing it too quickly.
Rene Russo is good value though her role is not large while the performances of the colleagues are amusing.
The only weak performance with a very flimsily developed and bland character comes from Anders Holm.
It looks good, it's slickly shot and edited and the locations and Hathaway's wardrobe are beautiful on the eyes.
The direction is mostly controlled and the film goes at a sprightly pace in the first half.

The irresistible charm and a script filled with pleasantly amusing lines and small scenes (such as De Niro turning up at the office in a suit, with a calculator and addressing himself, in a way that's very business-like, in the mirror that reminds one fondly of 'Taxi Driver') and wry observations and insight, taking care in making characters as amiable as possible while never fully developing most of them.
The story may lack depth and be unsurprising with some dramatic short cuts in the second half but mostly engages and is charmingly frothy and lively.
Sadly, things take a downturn in a jarring tonal shift to a clunky second half though thanks to De Niro and Hathaway it's not unwatchable.

Really admired what 'The Intern' did in giving Jules an arc and it was interesting to begin with, apart from benefitting from more show and less tell at how good she was at her job and such, but halfway through became awkwardly indecisive.
The sprightly, feel-good and very easy to warm to tone of the first half is replaced in the second half by pacing that tends to sag and things taking too much of a melodramatic and schmaltzy tone.
For instance the heart to heart/forgiveness scene could have been heartfelt but makes one feel nauseous instead.
The wry insights remain but the more sporadic comedic elements don't feel as well timed or placed.
As said, Anders Holm doesn't have the same enthusiasm as the rest of the cast and gets lost amidst everything else which does hurt Jules' character arc when she has such a dullard of a spouse.
The music score is nothing that sticks in the mind, for music that's pretty repetitive this was a problem.
Overall, decent enough film if one of two halves, starting off very well but later mostly goes down south.
6/10 Bethany Cox.
DeNiro Charms the Entire Cast Totally bored with life, Robert DeNiro's character seeks out a new career.
He had worked out, traveled the world, read books, on and on.
While he is relatively happy, he feels empty.
He is seventy years old when he reads a flyer on a bulletin board.
A rising company is looking for "senior" interns, that is, people who have had tons of experience who can be used as a kind of publicity stunt.
Ann Hathaway is the wunderkind of a clothing company that has feasted on the Internet.
DeNiro finds himself with no power, attached to Miss Hathaway, but doing no work.
Eventually, by taking on some of the hard work and showing utter kindness, he manages to become quite the institution in the firm.
His boss is trying to balance both her career and her marriage (and daughter).
At some point, it is decided that she should hire a CEO and give power over to him/her.
Soon DeNiro finds himself at the beck and call of Hathaway, becoming part of the family.
This is a touching, but predictable effort.
It's still a nice two hours and DeNiro steals every scene he is in.

nice pairing Ben Whittaker (Robert De Niro) is a 70 year old Brooklyn widower and a retired executive from the phone company.
His son's family lives out of town.
He tries to fill his days of leisure.
He spots a flyer advertising internships for senior citizens.
It's a fast-paced fashion internet commerce site run by Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway).
It's been a hectic 18 months for the married mother of little girl and she is reluctantly forced to use Ben as her assistant.
Her husband Matt gave up his job to be the stay-at-home dad.
Fiona (Rene Russo) is the company masseuse.
Ben befriends everyone until Fiona starts to find him indispensable.
Nancy Meyers gets a bad rap as the rom-com has become a passe genre.
This is not a rom-com but it is a friend-com.
De Niro is a little too perfect as the magical old guy with all the answers and lessons for the young ones.
This movie is a bit too neat and clean with the characters.
Hathaway is the driven multi-tasking internet executive.
The characters may be stock but the actors make them breathe.
Some of the side characters have some fun.
The big twist (not that surprising) does not really raise the drama although Nancy is trying to say somethings.
It all combines to create a nice pairing of these two great actors.
